metadata.synopsis: The first longrest in Undercity, Orin will abduct one of the players companion. (Lae’zel, Halsin, Gale or Minthara). Based on the players approval rating with them. (Friend, Good Friend and Romance) Highest approval will be the highest priority.She will appear in camp impersonating her abducted victim and toy with the players. Shortly after, she grows tire of the game and reveals herself. And gives her ultimatum - Kill Gortash and retrieve his Netherstone - and bring it to her at her Bhaal Temple. Or the abducted companion dies. She will then teleport away.
metadata.how_to_trigger: 1) Got the any Undercity location with Debugbook 2) -> Go to region 3) -> Act 3 4) -> Undercity 5) -> Bhaal Temple (or any other Undercity location).6) Add the companion to the camp with the Camp Debug Book.7) Go to camp by the Waypoint system, And start longRest by clicking on the bed/campfire.8) OR you can click the LongRest button from outside the camp which will end the day and teleport all to camp.9) This Campfire Moment dialog will trigger once the night starts automatically.

21.text: Forgive me. I was lost in my thoughts, as usual.
21.context: CinematicNodeContext: As the player enters camp, Gale stands gazing into the fire. He looks lost, brooding. Hearing the player approach, he turns to greet them.

42.text: I've found myself in something of a quandry. Yours is an opinion I'd gladly hear on the matter.

8.speaker: Player
8.text: You know I'll always help you.

7.text: Careful. You don't know what I'm about to ask.

41.text: I fear our unwillingness to make difficult decisions is doing more harm than good.

34.text: I regret straying from Mystra's instruction. All the suffering around us, it is our fault. I am reconsidering taking a more drastic approach.
34.context: NodeContext: Beginning to relate his issue

64.text: Every day we spend inching our way towards our enemies is a day we choose to let countless die in the Absolute's path.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: You think I've been holding back this whole time?

63.text: My apologies. I shouldn't place my own guilt onto your shoulders.

35.text: I'm afraid to say I have been holding back. Every. Single. Day.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: If 'drastic' means violent, then count me in.

16.text: As always, I'm grateful for your enthusiasm. And yes, it will require some amount of brutality on our part.

26.text: We both know the orb I carry inside me is powerful enough to burn away the Absolute's blight in an instant.

49.text: But what stays my hand? Obstinacy? Misplaced morals? Simple fear of dying? You?

11.text: The inevitable has been delayed far too long already - no more, I say. It's time to make a stand.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: But I thought you had your heart set on the Crown of Karsus? A difficult thing to aspire to, if you're dead.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: There's no need for anything so drastic. You thought the Crown of Karsus was worth pursuing...

5.speaker: Player
5.text: We haven't yet learned what the crown might be capable of. I thought you wanted to find out?

9.text: A passing fancy, one that has lost its lustre. No - unleashing the power within me will be far more magnificent than some crown.
9.context: NodeContext: dismissing his old opinion, growwing fervour/intensity - he's excited by this idea

52.text: The day will come when I lose control of the power within me anyway. There's nothing you or I can do to stop that.
52.context: NodeContext: assertive, not to be questioned

36.text: Gods damned if I'm going to let it be for nothing. If Mystra gave me one purpose, it was this: to destroy Baldur's Gate, and the Absolute with it.
36.context: NodeContext: Determined, this is the right thing to do

24.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale assumes a spell-casting pose, muttering a strange incantation. He begins to glow fiercely. The player braces themselves agains a brilliant flash of magic. The player staggers, then realises they're unharmed. They open their eyes, dazed. Instead of Gale, it is now Orin stood before us.NodeContext: Latin spellcasting, pronounced 'Kay-see ver-um vid-eh-ant' ('let the blind see the truth')

53.speaker: Player
53.text: So be it. End this, once and for all.

6.speaker: Player
6.text: A city snuffed out in one moment: it will be a beautiful offering for Bhaal.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: Try it, and you'll be dead before you utter your first syllable.

56.text: Kill me, and I'll destroy the city anyway.

18.text: So quick to turn on your friends... a sure sign of an unsound mind, and a villainous heart.

33.speaker: Player
33.text: Please, Gale. You're better than this.

2.text: There is nothing better than leaving in a blaze of glory.

45.text: So gentle. You think saving him will stop the bloodshed? It won't.

10.text: Most foolish. Wanton violence against your dear Gale? After all, the man has a budding apocalypse tucked beside his heart - you would provoke it?
10.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player readies their weapon, but Gale throws up a hand. The player hesitates.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: What makes you think it will work?

32.text: I know how much power rests within me - enough to turn Baldur's Gate to ashes, its memory to no more than a children's fable.

20.text: Act now, and we take out the brain and every footsoldier in the Absolute's army. All their hatred, their bile, their violence - erased. It would finally be over.

15.speaker: Player
15.text: It wouldn't only kill Absolutists - it would kill everyone. You can't be serious.

61.text: Deadly serious. This is the burden we must carry - to condemn the few to save the many, or Baldur's Gate will only be the first city to fall.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: I disagree. Using restraint has kept us alive so far.

12.text: That may be, but has it put a stop to the Absolute? Or cured us of our tadpoles?

44.text: All we've done is delay the inevitable, a delay that puts thousands more lives at risk. But those lives can be saved.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: Of course. What's on your mind?

60.speaker: Player
60.text: I didn't know you thought so highly of my opinions.

23.text: Of course! I find them to be almost the same quality as my own.

14.text: Just a bit of late-night humour for you. Your input would be most welcome.
14.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player raises an eyebrow.

4.speaker: Player
4.text: An intellectual dilemma to round off the evening? Sounds just the thing.

22.text: A puzzle for the mind, I'd solve quite comfortably. Unfortunately, this is a struggle for the heart.

57.speaker: Player
57.text: Sounds a bit heavy for so late an hour. Another time.

59.text: Wait. What I have to say... well, there may not be another chance. Please.
